document_metadata.name: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau

links.evidence: Addition of an equimolar concentration of Tau caused bundling of F-actin (Fig. 1b), although some single filaments remained

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: Quantification of the intensity of different bands indicated that ~63% of Tau remained in the supernatant. In addition, ~8% of Tau molecules were bound to single filaments, while ~29% of Tau was found together with actin bundles. The data demonstrate that Tau bundles actin filaments

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: The analysis reveals that the proline-rich regions P1âP2 and the four pseudo-repeats contribute to the Tau/F-actin interaction

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: The combined dataâ(i) competition of binding of Tau to F-actin by cofilin, which interacts with actinâs hydrophobic pocket, and (ii) residue-specific PRE effects in the repeat domain of Tau by preferential MTSSL-labeling of C374 in proximity to the hydrophobic pocketâsuggest that Tau binds to the solvent-exposed hydrophobic pocket that is located between subdomains 1 and 3 of actin

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: One of these binding partners is cofilin, a 21 kDa eukaryotic protein, which binds to F-actin with a Kd < 0.05 Î¼M33 and results in disassembly of F-actin34, 35. Cryo-electron microscopy further showed that the binding site of cofilin on F-actin is highly similar to its binding site on G-actin (Fig. 2a)32

links.evidence: The analysis suggests that the experimental NOE data witness the formation of helical structure in these regions upon binding to F-actin, but the number of detected restraints is not sufficient to define a unique conformation

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: In agreement with a decrease in affinity of Tau(254â290)-L266E for binding to F-actin (Supplementary Fig. 1), the mutant peptide was less efficient in promoting F-actin bundling (Supplementary Fig. 10f)

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: Sequential resonance assignment of the peptide (Supplementary Table 3), followed by NOE analysis (Supplementary Fig. 13) and structure calculations (Supplementary Fig. 14) showed that the short peptide folds into an Î±-helix (residues 259â265) in complex with F-actin that is similar to the one found in Tau(254â290) (Supplementary Fig. 14b)

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: Tau(292â319) comprises the residues of repeat R2 and R3, which experience strong signal attenuation upon addition of F-actin to full-length Tau (Fig. 1e, f). In agreement with the ability of Tau(292â319) to bind to F-actin, the peptide promotes bundling of actin filaments (Supplementary Fig. 5c)

citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: In most structures a 3â10 helix was identified for residues 315â318, although in the lowest energy structure residues 315â318 are in Î±-helical conformation (Supplementary Figure 12c)

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: An important class of kinases that phosphorylate Tau at S262 and the other KXGS motifs in the repeat domain are the microtubule-associated protein/microtubule affinity-regulating kinases (MARKs)

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: We therefore phosphorylated full-length Tau by MARK2. The downfield chemical shift of phosphorylated residues (Fig. 4a) is in agreement with previous reports and confirms phosphorylation at S262, S293, S305, S324, S356, and S416

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: The NMR experiments demonstrate that MARK2- phosphorylation of Tau attenuates its binding to F-actin. Consistent with a reduced affinity, MARK2-phosphorylated Tau failed in bundling actin filaments (Fig. 4e)

citation.name: Nature communications
citation.title: Multivalent cross-linking of actin filaments and microtubules through the microtubule-associated protein Tau.

links.evidence: The NMR experiments demonstrate that MARK2- phosphorylation of Tau attenuates its binding to F-actin. Consistent with a reduced affinity, MARK2-phosphorylated Tau failed in bundling actin filaments (Fig. 4e)
